episode.title: Bernhardt v. Polygraphic Company of America, Inc.

section.heading: Argument of Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: -- as a matter of the power -- the law of the specific States should govern and --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Before you -- before you -- may I interrupt this to --

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: -- ask you questions, please.
It -- does it show whether or not the petitioner withdrew from his agreement to arbitrate?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: The record show?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Does what show?

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Does the record show?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the record shows all the facts and as far as the withdrawal is concerned, there was no formal withdrawal but the bringing of an action amounts to withdrawal from --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Do you take that that's a withdraw?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
It's --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Would it be necessary for them to withdraw to raise the question for this case?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, perhaps we should use the word revoke rather than withdrawal because the action was begun prior to the commencement of arbitration.

In other words, we sued in Vermont, and then the other side would move to the federal court and substantially at the same time, began arbitration in New York and then moved to stay, pending the conclusion of the arbitration.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: It began arbitration?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: The --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: In your time that is here.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: That's right, Your Honor.
So that --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: If arbitration took place -- it would take place in New York?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it would take place before the American Arbitration Board, and they have an office in New York and -- and one in Boston, and they have provisions in their --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: But not in Vermont?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: No, but they have provisions in their rules for sending arbitrators out to wherever it might be.
And I assume under that that we could have the arbitration in Vermont which would be more convenient for both parties.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Well, do we have to decide in this case what state law controls?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: What state law controls?
Oh, I think so, Your Honor.
Our position is that Vermont state law definitely does control and as a matter of fact, our authorities for that, principally New York cases.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And do we have to decide what was -- assuming you're right, do we have to decide what Vermont law is, having no -- no light or have light shed on it from any of the courts below?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: As --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But we have to decide the question I put to you before noon?
Do we have to decide if -- if the stay become relevant, what New York is with reference to a contract executed in New York but the legal forum is Vermont without any light from the lower courts?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: My view is, Your Honor, that on the -- that what you really have to decide is whether this case comes under the Erie doctrine.
And if it comes under the Erie doctrine then Vermont law applies and the -- the only way to get to that -- to the New York --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I think it's -- is that necessary to this panel?
The Erie doctrine merely means that relevant state law and not some concoction of the federal court as to what is the general law, applies.
But that doesn't tell me what the relevant state law is.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, isn't that question what the Vermont -- what law the Vermont courts would apply?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that may -- they may not be but assuming it is, have we determined -- do we know, the answer eventually does or an adequate certainty what Vermont law is on this subject?
All -- all we know is that Vermont law, that it rules out arbitration.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: You mean on the matter of conflicts, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.
This is -- this -- this is a New York -- all these went to that.
I mean hardly stay open in my mind, it couldn't be more open.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But if New York -- if this is a New York conflict.
In the first place, it maybe a question of New York law as to whether or not the law raise the performance of it.
In the second place, I do not know, why should I know what Vermont law is as to a contract to be executed in Vermont but -- to be performed in Vermont but executed in New York.
On the Vermont we have -- have a law different for what governing body as to a conflict of contracts which is made and is formed in Vermont.

In relation to a contract tat exists is made in New York with complete performance in Vermont and New York that has a law as to contracts made in New York to be performed in New York with different problems from contracts made in New York to be performed in Vermont.
Any one of those possibilities seem to me relevant, rationally speaking, aren't they?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think they are.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well then, therefore -- and therefore, the question is where do I get the answers to those.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is one of the Vermont (Inaudible) to go through -- then go through Vermont cases to find out?
One would get lost to that.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I don't -- I think, Your Honor, that we can help you sum on that.
As far as the actual conflicts question goes, there is virtually no Vermont law order but --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Therefore, we have to prophesize to what Vermont law would be if it came before the Vermont Supreme Court, is that right?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Vermont has always been a common law state and I think that the -- that the conflicts rule as far as common law goes on what Vermont should do on a contract that was executed in New York to be performed anywhere, provided the case as tried in Vermont, I think that conflict rule is decided by the New York cases of the Mitcham against the Railroad, of matter of Gant, of matter of (Inaudible), and matter of Berkowitz.
And those cases all hold that arbitration is a matter of remedy, and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If you prophesize that too much because it's a matter of remedy, you are next going to argue that it is a matter of remedy once it gets into the federal courts.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I think the distinction there is the distinction drawn in the Guaranty Trust case that what you're talking about is whether it substantially affects the result.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Very well.
In those New York cases, to call this remedy doesn't help too much.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it helps in the sense that it means that Vermont law rather than New York law governs.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But why.
We thought --

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It would just -- If I understand that, if I understand myself whether it's remedy or the substance with certain aspect is irrelevant to the question of enforcing, giving counsels in a case we move to the federal courts.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: That's --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You go after the different things.Namely, what -- what cloak we are speaking, substantially makes a difference.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is that right?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that' right.
That's as to one phase.
That is as to whether the state law or federal law applies.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Then once you've decided that state law applies, the question is, what is the state law?
And in Vermont, you're pretty much thrown back to -- well, the state law is the common law.
And then the next question is, what is the common law?
And that's where the Mitcham case and the cases that follow it establish what the common law rule is that would be enforced in Vermont.

And it's rather interesting when you talk about possible conflict between Vermont law and New York law, that even where New York, if this case was reversed as to locations, New York I suppose would enforce this arbitration agreement under the New York statute.
But the reason that they would apply that statute is exactly the same reason that we're relying on here for not applying it in Vermont.
In other words, they would apply it because the case was in New York and because it was a matter of remedy.

That was held in every one of the cases that either side have cited it from New York even -- even in the cases where the contract call for application of New York -- of New York law, the basis of the decision was that both parties were voluntarily before the New York court, and that New York would apply its own law as to this matter of remedy.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You say this according to Vermont law the question of remedy, is it?
Well, the common law would make it remedy --

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- and the common law you derive from the New York cases would have gone back when, is that right?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: That's right and they --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, you think if it's remedy in Vermont law, it isn't true under the Guaranty Trust Company to every question of remedy.
It means the opposite issues that every question of remedy of the State is enforced by the federal court, I mean that doesn't answer the problem, does it?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: No, it doesn't but in the very Guaranty case itself, the statute involved was the statute of limitations.
And that as you said in your decision in that case has been held to be a matter of procedure.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: For certain purposes --

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- not for purposes of implementing the Erie doctrine.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: That's right and I say the same thing about remedy in this case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

So -- all I'm suggesting is that -- that remedy is the most treacherous concept to be using in this particular problem because you have to say, "Yes, remedy for service purposes would not without that."

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's right, Your Honor, but we haven't found any way to get around the -- around the use of the term remedy.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But I thought the New York -- the Guarantee Trust Company tried to indicate that it gets you nowhere in those (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, that's right for the Erie purposes but you were --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what we've got here.
We've got an Erie purpose here, haven't we?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, but you also have the question of whether Vermont and New York law applies.
And that -- that's --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's a different question and --

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- from that -- on that belief conflict --

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- will be to call the state courts to say I couldn't get any by going to the Vermont cases, and sending to the New York cases because New York and Vermont, both the common law jurisdiction and the common law is that the New York Court of Appeals said it was, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I'm not relying solely on New York.
We have the Shafer case from Ohio, and then there are quite a number of other cases involving some decisions of this Court which followed that same principle.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well now, I assume -- assuming you're right -- assuming -- don't worry about the conflict problems, so called, and that a situation where Vermont says, "This kind of -- this question Vermont thought wouldn't deal remedy," we can't have this remedy in the sort of jury non-proper prejudice.
And we come to our federal problem.

Namely, is this the kind of thing by which the substantive law is enforced to take that remedy and therefore, the federal court on its own, (Inaudible) or resource to the remedy or must have take over from the State?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: We think that the Wilco cases, the primary answer to that, that it certainly does substantially affect the result.
And I'd like to read just a few lines from the opinion.

This Court there said, “In unrestricted submission such as the present margin agreements envisage, the interpretations of the law by the arbitrators in contrast to manifest disregard are not subject in federal courts to judicial review for error and interpretation."

And then a little later, they went on and referring to the Boyd case, they said, “We said in that case that the right to select the forum even after the creation of a liability as a substantial right and that the agreement restricting the choice would forth the expressed purpose of that statute.”

Now, in other words, I interpret that as meaning that in a situation which is rather similar, this right to choose a forum, and in that case it was a right to choose between a court of law and arbitrators, there's a substantial right in the Guaranty Trust sense.
And for that reason, the Court in that case refused to enforce arbitration.

Now, in your dissent there, as I understand it, you drew an analogy between the speedy trial of these people that contracted for and the tortuous conduct of cases in the State of New York where the dockets are crowded.

And in Vermont, I don't want to belabor the term policy, but in Vermont let us say there isn't any economic necessity for substituting this arbitration which gives you sort of half a loaf, but faster for regular trial by court and jury with all the rules of evidence that assure a correct answer but take longer.
Actually, in Vermont, it wouldn't take any longer.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Let me put this to you in view of that consideration of yours.
For purposes of argument, suppose the question had come up in the reverse, so as Vermont having arbitration law allows them and the New York didn't.
Now, this was removed to the New York, to the Southern District of New York where the calendar has been what denotes to them as you have been in -- in some considerable extent of what it is.

Would -- would the consideration that you advance the opposite of which that they have prevailed irrelevant to be -- in this matter to be determined by state of the calendar for one thing, is that relevant continuation?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And I mean -- my question doesn't mean to decline an answer.
I question (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: I was really simply trying to distinguish this situation from -- from your dissent in that case.
I'm afraid I'd go along with the majority.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I -- I do too.
It's been decided as the (Inaudible) clause by which dissent from court opinions are all the same, not one of which every quarter.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I thought perhaps I could satisfy you that the reasons for your dissent in the Wilco case don't apply here.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The best way to satisfy me in your coherent theory to be something that certifies --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: What -- what would happen, Mr. Ehrich, if this Court affirmed this.
You would then go before the New York arbitration, I suppose.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I believe we'd have to, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: And there, you would have the right to withdraw from the arbitration under your theory?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, not after this Court decided we didn't.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: No, no.
They didn't merely decide that in accordance with Article -- paragraph 3, isn't it?
Article III, that there'd be a stay and that you would have to undertake the arbitration (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the -- the only reason that we would have to go before the Arbitration Board is that in the District Court, the company which is quite normal, have put in a counterclaim for exactly the same amount as our client.
And before the Arbitration Board, that counterclaim is the -- the only matter at issue at this point, unless we go in and present our side.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Well, you --

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Now, the result would be if we ignore it that under the New York --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Well, I didn't say ignore it.
I said if we affirm this, you would have to appear before the New York Arbitration Commission.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, either that or have a default judgment against us --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Yes.
(Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: -- which would then be enforceable in the New York courts.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: So if you appear there, then wouldn't you have the right to raise every question in regard to the -- to the law of Vermont that you now or before the law has -- had a right to withdraw from the arbitration since they didn't know the decision?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I don't think so, Your Honor.
By analogy to these New York cases, I think if we appeared before the Arbitration Commission, we'd be in the same position as if both parties had voluntarily appeared before the New York court.
And in other words, we'd be submitting ourselves to the jurisdiction of New York and -- and so then the law --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Well, even though your (Voice Overlap) have said in -- in answer to this claim for arbitration, we announce that we have withdrawn from the arbitration agreement in accordance to the law of Vermont.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well -- well, I'm not sure but I think we'd be stuck with it.
The -- the contract provided for the jurisdiction of the New York courts.
And whether that would carry over to the Arbitration Board or not, I don't know.
But the -- it didn't provide the exclusive jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Well, that -- that's the very question you have before the District Court, isn't it?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: No, I don't think so because it didn't provide for the exclusive jurisdiction of the New York courts.
And as I understand that provision, it simply means that if either party goes before the New York court, the other party will be bound by the decision.
But in this case, both parties went into the Vermont court and that question hasn't arisen.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Ehrich, may I -- (Inaudible) case that that was a surprise about that decision.
The statute -- the statute changed that decision, didn't it?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it did --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that seems to me the old and the perfectly (Inaudible) but I don't think it has written that opinion.
But I don't see that -- I get any light on that from -- for our problem.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Because I talk in saying that arbitration relates to remedy.
Well, the point of that case is that New York disregarded a -- wouldn't enforce a provision we challenge to the court.
That -- that's the heart of that case which -- which to me is a little medieval.

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think Your Honor that you really have to read a string of cases there.
After the Mitcham case, there was Berkowitz case where they had a very interesting situation of two contracts providing for arbitration.
Both contracts made before the statute was enacted and an action on one of them was begun before the statute was enacted, and the other was begun after the statute was enacted.

And in that case, Cardozo held that this thing being a matter of remedy, that they would enforce arbitration in the second case because the lawsuit was begun after the action, after the statute was passed, but they would not enforce it in their first case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But why -- what -- what is the significance?
What's the importance of calling it a matter of remedy?
I don't understand it.
Suppose it was called only to substantive law as in Mitcham and reach the same result, wouldn't they?
Party said by agreements to decide by what substantive law contract it governed, it -- it -- wouldn't that undo it for purposes to decide and other rights should be enforced?

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr
turn.label: Mr. Manfred W. Ehrich, Jr.
turn.text: Well, my understanding is that in the Mitcham case, the substantive law of Ohio where the contract was drawn -- I think the contract was drawn in Ohio for performance and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't -- (Voice Overlap) the corporation as to what --

turn.speaker: manfred_w_ehrich_jr

turn.speaker: joseph_a_mcnamara
turn.label: Mr. Joseph A. McNamara

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, if you are right about it or if the matter is in doubt so we don't know until the Vermont place to have speech then the present problem doesn't arise.Because if Vermont would enforce this, certainly --

turn.speaker: joseph_a_mcnamara

turn.text: Oh, that's very true.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, how can we find that out?

turn.speaker: joseph_a_mcnamara
turn.label: Mr. Joseph A. McNamara
turn.text: Well, we have given in our brief here, I haven't gone into it and my brother intends to argue the question of conflicts of law, the contracts conflicts of law doctrine as we see it applied here.

turn.speaker: joseph_a_mcnamara

turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black

turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter

turn.speaker: joseph_a_mcnamara
turn.label: Mr. Joseph A. McNamara
turn.text: Century (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That you would say the law that everybody assumes to be the law of Vermont, the professional opinion is that that is still the law with reference to agreement made in Vermont by Vermont --

turn.speaker: joseph_a_mcnamara
turn.label: Mr. Joseph A. McNamara

turn.text: -- by Vermont --

turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But secondly, you say however that a contract made in New York or any other State looking to enforce it, any other State having an arbitration existing provision, lawful in that state and the New York law is after the arbitration statute made in New York or any other State such as scheme of law.

section.heading: Argument of Guy M. Page, Jr.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: I have been -- been listening to this last colloquy between Mr. McNamara and the Court.
Now, I think we ought to -- we ought to get it clear that we're dealing with -- with the two different kinds of situations here.
When we went into federal court, we went in, in reliance upon the construction of Section 3 which the Second Circuit had announced.
It's a construction of some 20 years of standing.

And the construction clearly made Section 3 applicable to our case and that was so under that construction without regard to whether we got in under Section 2 so that we would have had Section 4 remedies.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean the opinion by Judge Hand?
When you say the Court of Appeals and the Second Circuit, what do you imply?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: We had in mind the -- the --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: It was very good.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: And that's -- and hardly say now.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: I think it was Judge Hand in the Shanferoke case that started the ball rolling on the -- the disassociation of Section 3 from the rest of the Act.
That was picked up by Judge Goodrich, who -- who expressly held that Section 3 was disassociated and I believe there's another opinion in there.
But that did seem to be and as we studied those cases on, we felt and we apparently were vindicated in that feeling that the Second Circuit would make that construction of the Act.

Now, assuming that that is the construction which stands, that Section 3 is broadened up to touch this case or that this case would fit into Section 3 on any construction then we're faced to a one kind of problem of how much state law we're going to absorb under the Erie rule.

Now, somewhere, there's a limit to the amount of state law which gets absorbed into the federal court and we think that that limit certainly is reached where Congress has enacted a specific method of the federal courts doing their business as they have in the Arbitration Act.
Now, that's one situation.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, they must be careful about that because have -- so many justices found that opinion in the Erie case over on the ground and why all the -- why your swift -- why swift enticing was declared illegal and unconstitutional, although it's been there for nearly 100 years, was because even Congress couldn't even follow.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well, yes, I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) jurisdiction apply non-state law.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: We appreciate that it's a constitutional problem, and undoubtedly, there is some restriction from the power of Commerce for Congress to legislate a procedure for the federal courts.
We just don't think it's reached with the Federal Arbitration Act.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It may -- rather than to be said, it may not be only clear that Congress even acted to that constitutional problem that such would be by directing that it should be applied to diversity cases.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: By directing that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That the Arbitration Act should govern diversity cases in cases where the State could be -- which is this situation on the first problem.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: So you put that in as a rule of construction?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's right, quite.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well, let's see.
I understand that admiralty case, that Red Cross case.

That the New York Court of Appeals doubted its own power to invade the federal domain to the extent of giving this remedy, this machinery for enforcing federally created rights or rights that originated in the federal domain.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr

But the point I was making now is we've got one problem when we're dealing with an act of Congress which has something to say about the way the federal courts are run, that is arbitration or not.

And we have quite a different situation if that act of Congress, for some reason, doesn't apply on this case, and there, we suspect that the amount of state law that's going to be absorbed is quite a good deal or more.
We think that's the -- that's the teaching of the York case that you've got to come up with a substantial result.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
