turn.text: (Inaudible) can't agree on that.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I -- I haven't heard anybody say no otherwise --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: We think so.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Now, I want to go back to just what this agreement is that we're dealing with.
We -- we feel that this -- this contract that's here being -- being construed, this breach of contract question as before the Court has got nothing to do with these old Vermont cases.
These were all domestic submissions.
They were -- they were matters which were submitted to arbitration for some reason or other.
There was a revocation which apparently satisfied the counsel that it had been an effective revocation.
And so, the -- the submission was a dead letter as far as affecting the resolution of the differences in court.
And that's all in the world those cases have anything to do with, they aren't our case.
This would be a case of first impression in Vermont.
As a matter of fact, we think it's a case of first impression here in this Court too.
So we think the Vermont cases such as they are have nothing to do with it.

Now, if I were under Vermont subject, I think I have heard in Mr. Justice Frankfurter's questions a suggestion that perhaps there is some burning local issue here which ought to be adjudicated for the first time in the Vermont court.
I don't think there is.
I think if you stop 9 out of 10 lawyers on the streets of Burlington and asked them what they thought about arbitration, they wouldn't have an opinion.
They wouldn't care much.

I've seen it once or twice in the local agreements but as far as whether the states barred or against it, and whether our courts work fast enough without the assistance of this extraordinary forum, I never heard the matter discussed except in connection with this particular case that we've been engaged in.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: We have so -- we have so many other practice up there that this wouldn't be a verdict problem.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: I don't think you could get the legislature excited about this at all.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Let me ask you this, Mr. Page, have you out of the category judgment law office?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir, we do.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How quickly could one get a determination by the Vermont Supreme Court on the judgment?
I should ask you, I don't think (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well, Mr. McNamara has been around the courts more than I have.
He just said a year and I suppose --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: A year, that speed in that place where you have such -- we just heard what an ideally conditioned (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's down in Bennington County.
[Laughs]

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: We're a little more rushed up in Chedington.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: I think it would take quite a long time.
I don't believe that the federal court opted staying from deciding this case on the ground that it's Vermont's business.

We really think it's a question which -- and we suspect the granting of certiorari here suggest that this Court feels that it affects a lot people -- a lot of people other than the ones involved in this case.
And if I had to make a guess, I would say people on -- in Vermont whereas little affected by it as -- as almost any people I could think of in the United States.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Well, if we left the whole problem of arbitration for a moment and thought of what the law in Vermont was as to the interpretation and enforceability of contracts made in another States, governed by the law of the other States according to the language of contract, then were drawn in Vermont.
Have we any light on that?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I think there is a little bit.
Certainly, our basic proposition up there is the lex loci governance, and that's nothing unique to our State.
There is more or less by happens stands one case here as in years ago where our court found occasion to remark the -- the law in governing an arbitration bond.
I think there, the matter had gone through to award and it was an action on the bond.
And they made some remark to the effect that the matter governing this arbitration business was -- was the law of Canada.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: But the -- the lex loci is there -- there, the law ordinarily enforced in Vermont?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: I don't think there's any question about it.
There's no special gimmicks on the Vermont law there, they are few cases involving it.
There are some -- some language in the cases which say that the parties -- which suggest the parties --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Have you -- have you discussed that question?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: We have not perhaps discussed to it as extensively as we should have.
I've got here on page 37 of -- of the respondent's brief.
We mentioned three cases there.
This Woodrow v. O'Conner is that old arbitration bond case.
And then there were a couple of cases more recent which suggests the parties can -- can have something to say about the applicable law.
By the way, they write their contract.
I did put in that Brown v. Perry case on this business of public policy.
I have a suspicion that some of the inquiries made by the Court on that are -- are whimsical in part as to whether or not we have a strong animus against arbitration.
If we have, I've never heard of it.
Here in this Brown v. Perry case, the Court laid down its rule, the rule for guidance when it's dealing with a statue of another State.

And I think it's worthy of quotation, ”A Court should not -- this is a Vermont Court speaking, “In otherwise proper cases refuse to apply the law of a foreign State, however unlike it's own, unless it is contrary to pure morals or abstract justice or unless the enforcement would be an evil example and harmful to its own people.”
The statute of another state is not contrary to public policy merely because it's materially different from our own or because we have no statute on the subject.
Now, if there's any question of pure morals or abstract justice involved here, I suspect our court would take a view that a fellow ought not to have it made easy for him to welch on an agreement.
But we think that's -- if there is any moral question involved then it's along those lines rather than this -- this ousting the court of jurisdiction.
There's a case back -- this fits in the old general law category back in 1918.
As a matter of fact, it's the principle authority for the quotation was Biehl.
There's a case that a man named Hough wrote -- wrote the opinion in the Southern District of New York.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Can you spell it, Mr. Page?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: H-O-U-G-H.
Yes, sir.
I know nothing about him --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) He's a very great man.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: It's a -- it's a fine opinion, [Laughs] that's all I know.
That he there said that -- that he had to follow the United States Supreme Court because he was a federal judge, and he would follow this old revocability cases which are matters of general law.

He said that in the last paragraph.But before saying that, he took 8 or 10 pages to excoriate this revocability rule, and we'd -- we'd cite that to the Vermont court if we had had -- we were put to it on this business of the pure morals and abstract justice and that sort of thing.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You -- do you claim hard if -- if your (Inaudible) follows the lines in view of your associate, Mr. McNamara, is that all this question of whether Erie-Tompkins absorbs this agony of pressure or doesn't, doesn't matter because in your case, you asked for enforcement of the New York contract.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: That's our position.
We think --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's your position that if you --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: This is a New York agreement.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Persuade the Court of Appeals to that position.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: No, sir that's -- well, I think perhaps I should explain why we did not.
We went into Federal District Court and we had some briefing done on that.
It isn't as thorough as we've gotten into later because of the time limitations.
And I got about partway through it and that the Court told me he didn't take much of my ideas.
So then we switched over --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did he say that just like that?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I can't remember his exact words, but he made it --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: More gentle, I suppose.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well, pretty much along those lines.
So at any rate, I thought I'd better switch over into the federal statute into that.
And we thought we're on pretty good ground on that federal statute, and the Court of Appeals thought we were.
But we don't -- the granting of certiorari here, we thought we better go back to some of these matters which are -- are independent of the statute.
And that's why our brief reads the way it does in this Court.

This -- I want to go back again on this business of exactly what the contract is we're dealing with because I think that's how you get -- that's the answer to these cases in that particular contract that was made.
Now, Mr. McNamara started to read that up, so it's a pretty good idea that we're construing an agreement to have the agreement here before us.

"The parties hereto do agree that any differences, claim, or matter in dispute arising between them out of this agreement or connected herewith shall be submitted by them to arbitration, by the American Arbitration Association or its successor.
And that the determination of the American Arbitration Association or its successors or any arbitrators designated by said association on such matters shall be final and absolute.

The said arbitrator shall be governed by the duly promulgated rules and regulations, the American Arbitration Association or its successor and the pertinent provisions of the Civil Practice Act for the State of New York relating to arbitrations.
The decision of the arbitrator may be entered as a judgment in any court of the State of New York or elsewhere."
And in this fourteenth article, they expressly incorporate this New York law in the agreement.
So this contract embodied this New York doctrine as a part of it.
And these provisions, Section 1450, of course we have the basic provision in Section 1448 which says that these agreements shall hereafter be valid, enforceable, and irrevocable.
Now, the legislature conceivably could have put a period to the statute right there and that would have been the end of it.
That I guess, everyone would say that sounds pretty substantive and we might not be arguing this remedy business.
Well, they didn't do that in order to implement this declaration that it was valid, enforceable, and irrevocable.

They went ahead and provided that when you make an agreement in New York, you consent in advance to the jurisdiction of the New York -- the courts over your person, so that you can't defeat the agreement by leaving the State.
They provided for a stay in Section 1451, not exactly the same stay we're asking for but a stay under their statutes.

In 1452, they gave the power to name an arbitrator and that stops all this chicanery of writings for scratching every name off the list that's submitted to you so that you can put it off indefinitely.
1461, they said that this award could become a judgment.
In 1466, they said it will have the same force and effect as a judgement.
The cases which have come up under the statute amply are a fruition of these provisions.
There is the -- the Marsh case, a Massachusetts contract made in Massachusetts.
Performance of the container contracts certainly at Massachusetts.
Nothing said about the place of performance of the arbitration clause and main in New York parties.

The New York Court of Appeals had no difficulty in saying that this thing should be enforced according to its terms, and they presented a moving party with a judgement which was entitled the full faith and credit in other States.
But there has incidentally been since the Shafer v. Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, so far as I know, there has been no -- no quarrel about the effect of these ex parte awards.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Perhaps in New York, has there ever been a case in Vermont since the beginning of its history in which it has sustained an agreement made in that State between parties which ousted the jurisdiction of this Court to any extent to federal controversies by lawsuits?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: I don't think there's been anything said one way or the other.
I don't think there's anything about ousting the Court's jurisdiction in Vermont cases.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Has there -- has there ever been any contract sustained in Vermont which where the parties agreed to change the rules of evidence in the court of law?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) I don't --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Or the burden of proof.
The burden of proof or anything like that.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: I can't offhand think of anything of that sort.
We looked a little bit along those lines for something -- of course, we weren't going to find anything on point of something peripheral.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes, I just wondered if you --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: I don't recall finding anything.
Now, the lawyers being what they are, sometimes, they find something they don't like and forget about it.
But I -- but I don't remember anything of that sort.
And I don't -- there was nothing very discouraging if I didn't do it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And did judge -- and Judge Gibson held, did he, that they could not do that?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well, he --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: -- done if I know just what he did he hold.
He -- I know he licked us.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: [Laughs]

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: He -- he went ahead and said that if we convinced him they showed him the need, he'd enjoin us from proceeding that arbitration in New York.
But as just what he held on this Erie v. Tompkins rule --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm not talking about Erie v. Tompkins.
I'm -- I'm talking about -- you said that Vermont has believed in keeping a contract which I think is great.
But do they believe in keeping contacts there made between parties which oust the court of a jurisdiction to try their lawsuit once the controversy arises?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: I don't believe that question has ever been presented in that fashion to the Vermont Supreme Court.
And I don't -- unless memory is playing me tricks here, I don't think there's any such discussion of that in the old Vermont cases.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that's the basis they admit on which they declined to recognize arbitration.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The Vermont agreement --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: I guess that's one of the things that these old cases used to say.
I think they have some other (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You've based on the argument they had a right to have a trial in this Court according to the rules of evidence and by jury, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the judge --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I -- I'm not talking --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I think probably that is one of the -- one of the explanations which was given.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What does your Constitution provide about trials by jury?
Does it make any provision on this?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, there is something in the Constitution about a jury trial.
We don't --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm just thinking about the policy of the State, isn't it?
That's a --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Say, I have something a little bit on our Vermont arbitration years and years ago.
It's not than I have ever seen in the modern day and age and it's washed out of our rule book now.
But years ago, there used to be a submission by rule of court.
And once there have been a submission by rule of court, I think there's -- some of these cases in the federal reporter or not the federal reporter but way, way back.
Once that had been submitted by rule of court, they discontinued the main action, and those parties were bound by their submitting there.
Now of course, they had to go in -- they had to have the consent to get into that situation.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And have on whose consent?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: They had to have the consent of the parties at the time the submission was made.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: But once a fellow had submitted, then the gavel had come down, he couldn't get up and revoke later on.
He was bound just as surely as a fellow was bound in New York State today.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Can they come back and -- was the award made a matter of the record in the Court in that action?
I should suppose so.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: I think so.
Although, there is some language also about the action -- the main action being discontinued.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Might of vagueness, this is -- this is --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Or -- or possibly suspended but there are three or four of those -- those cases.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that's what I understood from both of you, which probably the rule today with reference to arbitration.
Namely, as the parties came into court and agreed to arbitrate, they could arbitrate --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- at that time after the lawsuit is filed.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But that they couldn't make the agreement in advance.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, I suppose the -- of course I don't know.
Maybe our court would depart from those old cases.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Oh, yes, I understand it fine.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I would think if -- purely domestic arbitration agreement is made in Vermont today that there's nothing to stop one fellow from -- from revoking or backing out of it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But he couldn't do it, could he, if he agrees after the lawsuit starts and go into the judges.
I -- am I wrong in thinking that --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: I think once he's told the superior judge and the superior judge has made an order that they go ahead and submit this to arbitration, I think if he walks in the next day and said judge I -- I've changed my mind on that.
The judge would have a -- would be correct in saying that he couldn't change his mind, and that award would -- would settle his rights whether he attended that hearing or not.
He couldn't get out of it then under Vermont law.
But that's -- that's rule of the court stuff.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Page -- Mr. Page, suppose you and your senior pre-contradicted if this case arises.

If this question -- if the question was argued today before the Vermont Supreme Court, were the contracts entered in good faith on the verdict in New York for execution in Vermont carries with it, it does not illegalize or render nugatory of provision in the contract for arbitration, doing that is the normal thing to do in a New York contract.
Both of you are pretty confident by assertions, one for it.
Does that -- Vermont Supreme Court -- is that properly argued, meaning they're argued by you.
(Inaudible) is that fair to get to your argument?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well, we think this Court could give him some guidance to get through this -- this remedy confusion business.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I mean isn't that fair?
As far as Vermont law is concerned, you're pretty confident that they wouldn't say, “Oh, 19 of dissents he rendered the decision, there's a man who did there and we're going to stick to that.”

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Certainly, I hope there wasn't.
I don't know.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The prophecy that they would.
Otherwise -- and if that isn't so, that's your chief reliance, isn't it?
That Vermont law --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, yes.
I think we have to take that -- that position here if your question means, do he want to back and try that on a --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: -- declaratory judgment.
I don't want to do it.
We can help him.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Naturally, you came here.
I'm not saying that you want to exerting the (Inaudible) but I'm suggesting that might (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I think --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- starting off with Vermont law isn't for you and me to guess about.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well now, I have one other thought that may -- that may -- that might change your thinking on that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: I -- somewhere in our brief here toward the end, we have taken the position that there isn't any more federal general law of arbitration.
That stuff is all gone with Erie.
And when this -- these things --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that they --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There isn't a general law of it.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: There isn't any general law doctrine such as Judge Hough applied in the Trinidad case that the old Supreme Court cases are no longer authority because there isn't any federal common law anymore.
All of the cases which have come in thus far into federal courts since the Erie case, I think all of them have involved the Arbitration Act.
And this expansion of Section 3 has really displaced the -- the ordinary diversity case in the federal court.
They -- they do the same thing that they did in our case as we ask them to.
They apply the Federal Acts so you don't at least get -- they haven't really gotten into this Erie stuff.
Now, what happens when you get a -- and it's bound to come up sooner or later, particularly the uniformed commissioners enact this law, are successful in getting it enacted in more states.
What happens when you have these cases coming into the federal courts and into the state courts in the conflict of law situations?
Brother Ehrich is not too far wrong when he says about the only authority on it are things like Biehl.
And incidentally, Mr. Biehl doesn't think much of the rule.
He refers to it as a lot of chicanery I think.
And cases like the Shafer-Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer which is as dead as the dodo bird in its own state just as the Mitcham case, it's dead as the dodo bird in New York State.
That's all the law there is on this subject or just about all the law.
This 153 case in Pennsylvania where for some reason, they couldn't qualify under the Pennsylvania Act and with that opinion.
I can't understand what they said, but I know what they did.
They went ahead and stayed the action.
But more or less by analogy to what they would have done if their own Act applied and by analogy to what the New York State would have done.

But we think if this Court and I don't know how much attention people would pay to the Vermont Supreme Court if it made this distinction, but we think if this Court identifies the New York agreement embodying as it does in this statute as suspending the rights of the parties to a common law determination, to a determination of the common law courts and substituting their perspective arbitration award as their right.
We think that if that identification of the contract was made, then all these conflict of jurisdiction stuff will earn itself out.
Everyone can then think in terms of lex loci and lex fori and -- if there's no more trouble.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Those are very clear on this.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Pardon me, sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Those are very clear always, you think, easy to find out.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: The lex loci?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if this Court says that the New York statute means what it says that these things are enforceable and valid and revocable, I'd -- I think the Vermont Supreme Court would have less trouble and it would gone in on a declaratory judgement.
Now, of course we --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: We -- if this Court would say that the New York statute where the contracts made in New York, is made in the context of the New York statute and the full faith and credit law requires that to be irrespective throughout the country that has to reach?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well, yes.

We think it would -- if you go far enough to make -- as if you identify the thing strongly enough to make it work in the contract of law -- in the conflict of law context, unaided by any constitutional requirements.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, but this Court -- if this Court makes pronouncement and conflicts of law unaided or unrelated to the requirement of the full faith and credit law?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it might --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: With that power.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: It might have to --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It might be a good (Inaudible) -- I -- I know there's already in that jurisdiction all over the United States but I didn't know we did.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: As far as -- as -- I think this Court would have the power to ascertain Vermont law for purposes of deciding this case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, it would, certainly.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Whether to decide whether -- whether that kind of premise, if the federal court would enforce Vermont law.
Otherwise, the Vermont law --

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- would be relevant.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: If the statute looks after everything then of course I --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Was the Vermont law presented to the Court of Appeals?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: I -- Mr. McNamara argued that, I didn't.
Fred Ehrich have presented something along those lines, but we took the position that the statute was all --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Or you needed the rights of the federal statute?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: That was the position we took there.
We think this -- but just to close here, we think that this stay that we are asking for is not the New York contract stay.
It's a plea in the nature of a plea to suspend the operation of the petitioner's lawsuit until such time as his rights are fully matured by obtaining the arbitration award.
We think that's the thing he really has to sue on, is the arbitration award when and if he gets it.
And that our plea for a stay is -- is merely to get that award.

There is a couple of Vermont cases where they say that the proper thing for a court to do is to stay a pending action or is to stay the -- the reported action when there is another pending action that's going to get rid of all the problems.
It's going to make everything res judicata or collateral estoppel.
They simply stopped that second action and awaiting until the first one is finished and they do that by a stay procedure.
So --

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: Mr. Page.

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir?

turn.speaker: harold_burton
turn.label: Justice Harold Burton
turn.text: Would you state in closing which one of these several periods you've been arguing to place your main reliance upon?

turn.speaker: guy_m_page_jr
turn.label: Mr. Guy M. Page, Jr.
turn.text: We -- we feel exactly the same way here we did about Section 3 in the Circuit.
Putting aside Section 3, we think this thing ought to be entitled a full faith and credit.
We say that the public acts of New York are so much an integral part of the contract that the -- that the contract itself is entitled a full faith and credit in Vermont.
We think once this is done then all these monkey business will be over right there and that's -- that's the end of the matter right there and no more problems.
So that is our main position.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Clark.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: If the Court please.

I don't know as I can remember each of the individual questions asked in this discussion of this nutty problem and I hope that if there is anything that I forget to address myself in the way of questions that -- has already been put by members of the Court that they will please address the questions again because I will -- I would be delighted to try to answer them if I can remember them all.
I might say in regard to the Vermont law that in the first place --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: The Vermont law was before the District Court was it?

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: Yes.
The Vermont law as to what -- as to the enforceability of arbitration agreement was specifically decided by Judge Gibson.
In fact, he was so certain of the law himself that he asked counsel if they would be willing to concede that Vermont law was as we said it was and they did.
And so we did not argue that question orally other than a few preliminary statements before he made a statement.
Judge Gibson, a federal judge, a Vermont lawyer sitting in Vermont, made an express finding on that matter of Vermont law.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where is it?

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: That question was not disturbed by the Circuit Court of Appeals.
In fact, it was again conceded in oral argument by counsel, Mr. McNamara, so that we did not again address ourselves orally to that problem.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: But that was on the question, was is not, of -- of whether -- whether Vermont law --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: -- was related to arbitration --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: That is --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: -- and not whether Vermont law on the contract.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: That is correct.
The matters of the conflicts problems which you are asking about now were briefed by both parties extensively at the District Court level.
And they were argued by Mr. Page and by ourselves at the District Court level.
Now, the District Court, perhaps unfortunately because the problem that's now raised here didn't expressly rule on the conflicts argument.
He seemed to dispose of the whole thing in a -- in a package statement with reference to the Erie doctrine.
The question was argued and briefed for him.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If they can't (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But not -- not before the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: Not before the Court of Appeals because their appeal was based solely on what they interpret to be his -- Judge Gibson's mistake on the Federal Arbitration Act, Section 3.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Clark --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- it's more than a conflict argument that is made by the particular --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: The full faith and credit.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The full faith and credit argument.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: Now, let me say something about that if the Court please.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean the conflicts argument --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: As you had --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- we don't know -- we don't simply as a court pronounce in conflicts of law for the -- for the country at large.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: Well, if the Court please.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I know that's a very inviting field to enter but that is in the -- within our confidence.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: This case does have three --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Your conflict argument going to be --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Won't the conflict argument be the determining factor in this case?

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: Yes.
It's this -- this case really in my view has three aspects or at least all of which are crucial.
We say that the question of the Vermont law of enforceability was settled at the District Court level.
I don't think that you could pick a court more unlikely to reverse itself on a question that it has pronounced in -- in several judicial opinions, however ancient than the Vermont Supreme Court --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But Mr. Clark --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: -- without benefit of a statutory amendment.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Clark --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- isn't that to make distinction between an agreement made in Vermont --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: I do.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- to rub on both for execution in Vermont and an agreement made in New York right into Vermont --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: I do.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- for execution there.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: I do.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And -- and --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: If the Court please, as I said, there are three aspects.
I'm trying to dispose of the first one first because I think that that's the most easily disposed off.

That's the question of what is the Vermont law on arbitration agreements, not the conflicts question which you raise nor the full faith and credit question which can be discussed following that if I may.
The Vermont law is settled.
Now, Vermont courts aren't given the (Inaudible)
They made no statement that arbitration was a horrendous thing.
They merely stated the law as they found it at that time.
I take that to mean a statement of policy.
There might be very many factors that might have determined what the policy would be at that time.
It has been accepted by -- as the counsel for the other side is as the Vermont law all these years by Vermont lawyers.
And Judge Gibson thought it was so well settled that he didn't even ask for argument on the question.

We feel that this policy question has some relation to the full faith and credit issue however, and we do feel that it is important that this Court not try to remake the law for Vermont under the guise of full faith and credit merely because it doesn't find a shattered statement in the Vermont Supreme Court as to why they rule the way they do on arbitration agreement.

Now, in the very case which they have cited at length with regard to the view of Vermont case of conflicting policies, the Brown against Perry case, I should point out that in that case, it involves an application of the Hew Hampshire wrongful death action, if I remember rightly, in Vermont courts.
Now, Vermont had a wrong -- wrongful death statute at the same time.

There was no conflict of policy there as such but in fact, the people who won in that case won a pyrrhic victory in a way because the reason they wanted the New Hampshire statute was because the measure of damages was much broader.
It include pain and suffering of the decedent.
And at that time, all Vermont permitted was loss to the next of keen, pecuniarily loss to the next of keen.
And it is a striking fact that the Court in that Brown against Perry case decided that, "Yes, we apply the Vermont -- the New Hampshire statue in Vermont as to wrongful death.
But the measure of damages being a matter of remedy, we apply."
So that people that won that appeal were nothing because in fact, the measure of damages is probably what they were concerned for.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Was that decided by Vermont on Vermont conflicts law in full faith and --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: That was decided by Vermont.
They didn't mention the Full Faith and Credit Clause I might say.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They didn't or did?

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: They did not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did not?

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: Did not.
But if --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Because you got Vermont conflicts law, is it?

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: But it was a conflicts decision obviously and it did state that this a matter of remedy, the measure of damages.
Now, whether the measure of damages is every -- in view of everybody, I don't know.
I think that -- that remedy is --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I suppose --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: -- a useful distinction under some circumstances but it obviously is a fighting word in many cases.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. -- Mr. Clark, I suppose if you had a Vermont statute which for certain, (Inaudible) is double damages and the suit was then further moved to the federal court.
I should think anybody would have a hard time arguing with the measure of damages as a matter of remedy.
And therefore, the federal court would apply the old remedy and therefore the Government and its provisions, the Vermont statute doesn't apply.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: That's right.
There you have --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that would be a dollar and cent establishment of substantiality.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: That -- that is correct and that's where the Erie and Tompkins case comes in of course.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did Judge Gibson, as I read his opinion, he squarely decided that this particular contract which was made in New York --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- by these parties --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- was not enforceable under Vermont law?

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: He did said that Vermont law did not permit the enforcement of arbitration agreements.
That the contract was then --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But what agreement was he talking about?

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: This very one we're --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Made in New York?

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: -- talking about here.
Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And are they --

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: But, he did not mention in his position -- in his opinion New York law.
That was all presented to him in argument in the courts.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Certainly, he didn't mention it in is his opinion but when he held on page 17 that there was no statutory law governing arbitration, common law must apply.
The common law is an agreement to submit an issue of arbitration is not binding, it is not revocable at anytime and then enforce this.
He was enforcing this particular contract made in New York.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: That's correct.
That is correct.
I think that the conflicts rule is implicit because it was necessary to his decision in the first place.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, he had to do that because he gave his second question -- he is deciding upon it of that and be contracted to a just contracted dispute by arbitration and then you said they haven't.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: If he had expressly said I also decide the conflicts issue and then made a ruling on that and then applied the Erie to it with facts and against the dissenter and all that --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Well, he goes through.
I -- I suppose the Court of Appeals went the other way.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: The Court of Appeals apparently went on the Murray against -- Murray against Mitsui case.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: Yes, if -- if it is necessary to decide the Vermont law in order to keep this from being arbitrated in Vermont, it was necessary for the Court of Appeals to decide it contrary as to Vermont law for it to go to stay in New York law.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: No, they decided the -- entirely on the basis of federal statute, saying merely a form of trial something which is within federal jurisdiction and subject to the power of the federal courts -- of the Congress to control through their control of procedure in federal court.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They held that the Erie and Tompkins doctrine didn't apply?

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: That is right.
That's exactly what they decided, and we of course disagree very strenuously for -- with that.
But on the other hand, I gather that counsel have already agreed possibly in view of the Wilco case that this is a type of -- of situation which would substantially affect the result.
And perhaps the Court isn't willing to let it go on concession of counsel.
I'd be willing to address myself to that further if you feel that that's necessary.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I think your time has expired Mr. Clark.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: Oh, there --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: [Laughs]

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is to bring another case as equal to this case so we could have some more discussion to the matter before us.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: But could I make one closing statement, if the Court please.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, if it will -- if it's just a statement, it won't take time.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: In this matter of Gant decision which they also rely on in New York's Court of Appeals.

The New York case said specifically, "We treat this matter of enforceability as a matter of remedy, and they expressly rejected order of Travelers against Wolfe as being applicable and is requiring full faith and credit.
They said we, however, do not think that that decision wipes out the old rule that remedies including arbitration are regulated by the law of the forum.
Now in summary, I think that this case has to --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, I -- I think your time has expired.
You made your statement, Mr. Clark.

turn.speaker: eugene_v_clark
turn.label: Mr. Eugene V. Clark
turn.text: I'm sorry.
